10.0152 UNNECESSARY NOISE FROM SQUEALING TIRES/UNNECESSARY
ACCELERATION/EMITTING UNNECESSARY AND LOUD MUFFLER
NOISES
A. No person shall make unnecessary and annoying noise with a motor
vehicle by squealing tires, excessive acceleration of engine or by
emitting unnecessary and loud muffler noises. (Ord. 2439 adopted
1-7-20)
City of Marinette 31 Code of Ordinances
10.0200 bicycles and skateboards
10.0201 CLINGING TO OTHER VEHICLES
No person shall operate any bicycle upon the streets of the City or permit any one
to ride with him on such bicycle at any time. No operator, or any person riding
upon a bicycle, shall cling to or attach himself or his bicycle to any other vehicle
moving over or upon the streets of the City.
10.0202 TRICK RIDING
No operator of a bicycle shall perform tricks or stunts while riding on the City
streets and shall keep both hands upon the handle bars at all times except when
giving an appropriate signal to other traffic.
10.0203 RACING
No operator of a bicycle shall participate in any race speed or endurance contest
with the operator of any other bicycle or vehicle upon the City streets, unless
participating in an event authorized by the Common Council.
10.0204 BICYCLE PARKING
No owner or operator of any bicycle shall park on any sidewalk area or upon any
roadway in such manner as to interfere with free passage by the public.
10.0205 TRAILERS
No operator of a bicycle shall ride on the City streets with a trailer or coaster, toy
vehicle, hand sled, toboggan, or similar device attached.
10.0206 LIGHTS AND REFLECTORS
Every bicycle operated upon the streets during any of the time between one-half
(1/2) hour after sunset until one-half (1/2) hour before sunrise shall be equipped
with a lamp on the front exhibiting a white light visible from a distance of at least
five hundred (500) feet to the front and with a lamp on the rear exhibiting a red
light visible from a distance of at least three hundred (300) feet to the rear, except
that a red reflector approved by the Motor Vehicle Department of the State of
Wisconsin may be used in lieu of a rear light.
10.0207 RULES OF THE ROAD
The provisions of Ch. 346, Wis. Stats., shall be applicable to the operation of
bicycles where appropriate.
10.0208 OPERATION ON STREETS
No person shall ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk, except that a child's or trainer
bicycle with wheels of twenty (20) inches or less may operate on a sidewalk.
Every rider of a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as nearly as practicable within
five (5) feet of his right hand curb or right edge of the roadway except when
passing another vehicle or making a left hand turn at an intersection, and when
traveling in groups shall ride in a single file and not abreast unless unavoidable.
City of Marinette 32 Code of Ordinances
Bicycles may operate on bridge sidewalks, but shall yield the right-of-way to
pedestrians.
10.0209 LIQUOR AND DRUGS
No person shall operate a bicycle within the City while under the influence of
liquor or drugs.
10.0210 REGISTRATION REQUIRED
No person shall operate a bicycle upon any street in the City unless the bicycle is
registered and tagged as provided in this Chapter.
10.0211 REGISTRATION PROCEDURE
A. Repealed. See MMC Section 9.1302 (Schedule A).
B. Upon registration, an identification tag, serially numbered to correspond to
the registration number, shall be affixed to the bicycle.
C. In case of theft or loss of the identification tag, a duplicate tag shall be
issued for a fee of One ($1.00) Dollar.
D. A complete record shall be kept by the City Treasurer of all funds received
from registration of bicycles.
E. No bicycle shall be registered which is not properly equipped.
F. The Chief of Police shall have authority to suspend registration and
remove the identification tag for a period not to exceed ten (10) days, from
any bicycle operated contrary to any State law or City ordinance or
operated while not properly equipped. The suspension and removal of
registration tag shall be in addition to other penalties provided by this
Chapter.
G. No person shall willfully remove, deface, or destroy any identification tag.
H. Any sale of a bicycle by any person who does not sell bicycles in the usual
and ordinary course of business or other change of ownership of any
registered bicycle, shall be reported to the City Treasurer's Office within
ten (10) days after said transaction by the person in whose name the
bicycle is registered; the transferee/new owner shall comply with
subsection (a) hereof within twenty (20) days after said transaction.
10.0212 BICYCLE DEALERS' RECORDS
All persons engaged in the business of buying or selling new or used bicycles are
required to keep a bicycle sold record, giving the name and address from or to
whom each bicycle is purchased, the frame number thereof and the registration
number. The City Treasurer shall review such records periodically.
City of Marinette 33 Code of Ordinances
10.0213 REGULATION OF SKATEBOARDS
A. Definition
A skateboard shall be defined as any board or platform device having at
least two (2) axles with wheels on each end of a style commonly occurring
on roller skates, or any other similar device, such device intended to be
ridden by a person who propels him or herself by pushing the platform
forward and then riding upon it as it coasts.
B. Operation Prohibited in Certain Areas
The use of a skateboard by any person shall be prohibited in the following
locations:
1. Any public street.
2. Any public parking lot.
3. Any public sidewalk, except that skateboarding shall be
permitted on sidewalks in Single Family, One and Two
Family, and Multiple Family Zoning Districts.
4. Any public property where signs are posted prohibiting
such use.
C. Operators to Yield Right-of-Way
On any sidewalks where skateboarding is permitted, the operator of a
skateboard shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians. A skateboard
operator shall dismount when meeting or overtaking a pedestrian in such a
manner as to insure the safety of both the skateboarder and the pedestrian.
D. Penalties
Any person who shall violate any provision of this section shall be subject
to the penalty provisions of Marinette Municipal Code Section 1.0107, as
amended from time to time.
10.0214 IN-LINE SKATING REGULATIONS
A. Definition
"In-Line Skates" means skates with wheels arranged singly in a tandem line
rather than in pairs. (Wisconsin Statutes Section 340.01(24m).)
B. State Laws Applicable
Every person using in-line skates upon a public roadway shall be subject to
the provisions of all ordinances and State laws applicable to the operator of
any vehicle, except those provisions with reference to equipment of vehicles
and except those provisions which by their nature would have no
application.
City of Marinette 34 Code of Ordinances
C. Public Sidewalks or Walkways
Every person using in-line skates upon a sidewalk or walkway shall yield
the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall exercise due care when passing
any other person.
D. Riding on Roadway
1. Every person using in-line skates upon a two-way public street or alley
shall keep as close to the left-hand curb as possible and shall proceed
against traffic. Every person using in-line skates upon a one-way
public street or alley shall proceed against the one-way traffic.
2. Every person using in-line skates upon a roadway shall ride single file.
3. Persons using in-line skates upon a public roadway shall not impede
the normal and reasonable movement of motor vehicle traffic.
E.. Clinging to Moving Vehicles Prohibited
It shall be unlawful for any person using in-line skates to cling to or attach
to any bicycle or other moving vehicle upon a public roadway.
F.. Observance of Traffic Regulations
Every person using in-line skates upon a public roadway shall stop for all
stop signs and traffic signals.
G. Yielding to Traffic
The operator of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to a user of in-line
skates in the same manner as for bicyclists and pedestrians under Wisconsin
Statues Sections 346.23, 346.24, 346.36, and 346.38. When using in-line
skates, every person shall, upon entering a public roadway, yield the rightof-
way to motor vehicles, except that a person using in-line skates shall be
subject to the same regulation as bicyclists and pedestrians under Wisconsin
Statues Sections 346.23, 346.24, 346.37, and 346.38.
H. Equipment Regulations - Lamps and Reflectors
Every person using in-line skates between one-half (1/2) hour after sunset
and one-half (1/2) hour before sunrise shall be equipped with the following:
1. A lamp firmly attached to the front of such person exhibiting a white
light to the front visible at a distance of 500 feet.
2. A reflective material on the back of such person visible at a distance
of 500 feet when illuminated by the headlight(s) of a motor vehicle.
The reflective material shall be not less in area than the equivalent of
a circle (3") in diameter. A lamp exhibiting a red light visible at a
distance of 500 feet may be used in lieu of a back reflector.
City of Marinette 35 Code of Ordinances
10.0300 SNOWMOBILES
10.0301 STATE SNOWMOBILE LAWS ADOPTED
Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Chapter, the statutory provisions
describing and defining regulations with respect to snowmobiles in the following
enumerated sections of the Wisconsin Statutes are hereby adopted by reference
and made part of this Chapter as if fully set forth herein. Acts required to be
performed or prohibited by such statutes are required or prohibited by this
Chapter. Any future amendments, revisions, or modifications of the Statutes
incorporated herein by reference are intended to be made part of this Code.
10.0302 APPLICABILITY OF TRAFFIC REGULATIONS TO SNOWMOBILES
No person shall operate a snowmobile upon any street, highway, or alley within
the City of Marinette in violation of the traffic regulation provisions of Sections
346.04, 346.06, 346.11, 346.14(1), 346.18, 346.19, 346.20, 346.21, 346.26,
346.27, 346.33, 346.35, 346.37, 346.39, 346.40, 346.44, 346.46, 346.47, 346.48,
346.50(1)(b), 346.51, 346.52, 346.53, 346.54, 346.55, 346.87, 346.88, 346.89,
346.90, 346.91, 346.92(1), and 346.94(1), (6), (6m) and (9), Wis. Stats.
10.0303 PROHIBITED AREAS OF OPERATION AND DESIGNATED STREET
CROSSINGS
A. No snowmobile shall be driven on any grounds, parks, including public
sidewalks, pedestrian ways and areas reserved for parking which are under
the control and supervision of the City Council.
B. No snowmobile shall be operated on any City street or alley except as listed
in Subsection (C).
C. Snowmobiles shall be allowed on the following portions of City streets,
subject to all applicable state laws, rules and regulations, and City
ordinances:
1. Both sides of the right-of-way of County Highway T between Mary
Street and Old Cleveland Avenue excluding the roadway and shoulder
areas.
2. The crossing of Marinette Avenue that is located 350 lineal feet north
of Mary Street.
3. Along University Drive, between Shore Drive and Bayshore Street.
D. Snowmobiles may be operated at Red Arrow Park on snow having a depth
of three (3) or more inches.
10.0304 EQUIPMENT; LIGHTS
No snowmobile shall be operated within the City limits of the City of Marinette,
unless the same shall be in proper working order and fully equipped with a
functioning muffler and operating headlights and taillights. Any snowmobile
operating during hours of darkness shall display a lighted headlight and taillight.
City of Marinette 36 Code of Ordinances
10.0305 UNATTENDED VEHICLES
No person shall leave or allow a snowmobile owned or operated by him to remain
unattended on any public highway or public property while the motor is running
or with the starting key left in the ignition.
10.0306 RECKLESS DRIVING
No snowmobile shall be operated within the City limits of the City of Marinette in
a careless or reckless manner, or driven in any way which might endanger persons
or property of others, or under the influence of intoxicating liquor, fermented malt
beverages, narcotics, or other drugs.
10.0307 OPERATION ON PRIVATE PREMISES RESTRICTED
No person shall operate a snowmobile on any private property not owned or
controlled by him within the City of Marinette without the express consent or
permission of the owner.
10.0308 RESTRICTIONS ON OPERATORS
A. No person under the age of sixteen (16) years shall operate any snowmobile
upon any street, alley, or other public right-of-way in the City of Marinette;
and no snowmobile owner shall authorize any person under the age of
sixteen (16) years to operate such snowmobile upon any street, alley, or
other public right-of-way in the City of Marinette.
B. No person shall operate any snowmobile upon any street, alley, or other
public right-of-way in the City of Marinette unless such person shall have a
valid motor vehicle operator's license or unless such operator is
accompanied by a person who has a valid motor vehicle operator's license
and who is occupying a seat on the vehicle.
10.0309 MUFFLERS
No snowmobile shall be operated within the City of Marinette unless such
snowmobile is equipped with an adequate muffler in constant operation and
properly maintained to prevent any excessive or unusual noise or annoying
smoke. Excessive noise shall specifically include the unnecessary acceleration of
the engine. No person shall modify the exhaust system of any snowmobile in a
manner which will amplify or increase the noise emitted by the motor of such
snowmobile above that emitted by the muffler originally installed on the
snowmobile.
In this section, "muffler" means a device consisting of a series of chambers of
baffle plates or other mechanical design for receiving exhaust gases from an
internal combustion engine, and which is effective in reducing noise.
City of Marinette 37 Code of Ordinances
10.0310 OPERATION ON GREEN BAY
No person shall operate a snowmobile on Green Bay, within one hundred (100)
yards of the shore line, between Edwin Street extended and Cushman Street
extended.
10.0311 SNOWMOBILE ROUTES AND TRAILS
A. Permitted Areas
Snowmobiles may be driven on trails or in areas specially designated, under
the control of the City Council, when appropriate signs have been erected
giving notice that snowmobiles may be operated in the area.
B. Trail Markers
The Chief of Police or his designee is directed and authorized to procure,
erect, and maintain appropriate snowmobile route, trail, and limit signs and
markers as approved by the State Department of Natural Resources under
Section 350.13, Wis. Stats. The Chief of Police shall have the power to
declare the stated snowmobile routes and trails either open or closed.
C. Markers to be Obeyed
No person shall fail to obey any route or trail sign, marker or limit erected
in accordance with this Section.
D. Specific Trail Recognized
1. The City of Marinette permits the operation of snowmobiles on all
legally marked snowmobile trails located in the City of Marinette,
County of Marinette, State of Wisconsin and as referenced in Section
10.0303(c) of this ordinance.
2. Use of the trail shall be limited to snowmobiles during periods of
natural snow cover.
3. Recognition of any particular section of trail shall be valid only as
long as permission of the land owner of that particular section remains
in effect.
4. Owners and operators of snowmobiles on the trail shall obey, in
addition to Chapter 10, Section 10.0300, of the Marinette Municipal
Code, all applicable rules and regulations of the Wisconsin
Administrative Code and Chapter 350, Wis. Stats, as amended.
10.0312 PENALTY
Any person who shall violate any provision of this Chapter shall upon conviction
thereof forfeit an amount as found in Section 1.0107 of this Code of Ordinances
and the costs of prosecution and in default of payment thereof may be imprisoned
in the county jail for a time not to exceed ninety (90) days; provided no person
shall forfeit an amount in excess of the maximum fine or forfeiture allowed in the
City of Marinette 38 Code of Ordinances
Wisconsin Statutes for the same offense and further provided that the penalty and
forfeiture for parking violations on highways shall be the amount applicable to
such violations by owners or operators of motor vehicles under Sections 10.0140
and 10.0141 of the City of Marinette Code of Ordinances.
10.0313 ENFORCEMENT
A. Uniform Citation for Highway Violations
The uniform traffic citation promulgated under Sec. 345.11, Wis. Stats.,
shall be used for violations of this Chapter relating to highway use except as
herein provided.
B. Other Violations
All violations of this Chapter not described in Subsection (A) shall be
enforced in accordance with Sections 66.0114 of the Wisconsin Statutes.
Stipulations of guilt or no contest may be made as provided in Sec.
66.0114(1)(b), Wis. Stats., in substantially the form provided in the uniform
traffic citation within five (5) days of the date of the citation for such
violation. Bail deposits may also be made under Sec. 66.0114.
C. Police Department to Receive Stipulations and Penalties
Stipulations, forfeited penalties and deposits for obtaining release from
arrest authorized under this Chapter may be accepted at the City Police
Department offices by the Chief or officer designated by him. The officer
authorized to accept penalties and deposits shall be bonded and such bond
shall be filed with the City Treasurer.
D. Severability
If any provision of this ordinance or its application to any person or
circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect other provisions
or applications of this ordinance that can be given effect without the invalid
provisions of this ordinance are severable.
10.0314 OWNER’S LIABILITY FOR SNOWMOBILE VIOLATIONS
A. Owner’s Liability
The owner of a snowmobile involved in a violation of Section 10.0303,
10.0306 or 10.0307 shall be liable for the violation as provided below
B. A person observing any such violation may prepare a written report
indicating that a violation has occurred. If possible, the report shall contain
the following information:
1. The time and approximate location at which the violation occurred.
2. The registration number and description of the snowmobile involved
in the violation.
City of Marinette 39 Code of Ordinances
C. Delivery of Report
Within 24 hours of observing the violation, the person may deliver the
report to the Marinette Police Department.
D. Issuance of Citation
Within 48 hours after receiving the report, a police officer may prepare a
uniform Municipal Court citation and may personally serve it upon the
owner of the snowmobile. If with reasonable diligence, the owner cannot
be personally served, service may be made by leaving a copy of the citation
at the owner’s usual place of abode within this state in the presence of a
competent member of the family at least 14 years of age, who shall be
informed of the contents thereof. If with reasonable diligence the owner
cannot be served in either preceding manner or if the owner lives outside of
the jurisdiction of the City, service may be made by Certified Mail
addressed to the owner’s last known address.
E. Except as provided below, it shall be no defense to a violation of this
section that the owner was not operating the snowmobile at the time of the
violation. Defenses to a violation of this section are specifically limited to
the following:
1. A report that the snowmobile was stolen was given to the Marinette
Police Department before the violation occurred or within a
reasonable time after the violation occurred; or
2. If the owner of the snowmobile provides a police officer with the
name and address of the person operating the snowmobile at the time
of the violation and the person so named admits operating the vehicle
at the time of the violation, then the person operating the snowmobile
and not the owner shall be charged under this section.
F. The general penalty provisions in Section 1.0107 shall apply a violation of
this section.
10.0400 ABANDONED AND JUNKED VEHICLES
10.0401 VIOLATIONS
No person shall leave, park or store any motor vehicle, mobile home or trailer
within the City of Marinette for such time as to cause such motor vehicle
reasonably to appear to have been abandoned. Whenever any motor vehicle has
been allowed to remain standing on any street or public place in the City of
Marinette for more than 72 hours, the same vehicle shall be deemed to have been
abandoned within the meaning of this Chapter. No person shall leave any
inoperable, wrecked, junked, or unlicensed motor vehicle or a motor vehicle with
expired license plates on any street or highway within the City of Marinette. No
person shall park or permit to park any partially dismantled, inoperable, wrecked,
City of Marinette 40 Code of Ordinances
junked, discarded or unlicensed motor vehicle or a motor vehicle with expired
license plates on any premises in the City.
10.0402 REMOVAL AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES
Any vehicle in violation of this Chapter shall be removed and impounded until
lawfully claimed or disposed of under the provisions of Section 10.0403.
10.0403 REMOVAL, STORAGE, NOTICE, OR RECLAIMER OF ABANDONED
VEHICLES
A. Removal
1. Any sworn Officer who discovers an abandoned motor vehicle on
a public street or highway shall place a notice on a conspicuous
place of the vehicle notifying the owner of the removal order
including the date of notice. After 72 hours, that vehicle may be
removed to a suitable place of impoundment.
B. Storage and Reclaimer
Any abandoned vehicle which is determined by the Police Chief or his/her
designee to be abandoned shall be retained in storage for a period of ten
(10) days after certified mail notice, as hereinafter provided, has been sent
to the Wisconsin titled owner and/or secured party of record with the
Wisconsin Motor Vehicles Division. After giving proper notice as
provided for under this section and determining the vehicle is not reported
stolen or wanted for evidence, the Chief of Police or his/her designee is
hereby authorized to remove, store, or sell according to procedures set
forth in 342.40(3) (c) and (e) Wis Stats., or by private contract in
accordance with 779.415 Wis. Stats. The vehicle may be released to the
legal titled owner or lienholder after all associated towing and storage fees
are paid. Towing fees are listed on the current Towing Bid Contract
between the City of Marinette and the contracted towing service. The
owner of any abandoned vehicle, except a stolen vehicle, is responsible for
the abandonment and all costs of impounding and disposing of the vehicle.
Costs not covered from the sale of the vehicle may be recovered in a civil
action by the City against the owner.
C. Adoption of state law. The provisions of Wis. Stats. Sec. 342.40 and Wis.
Stats. Sec. 779.415, related to abandoned vehicles are hereby incorporated
by reference; in case of conflict between the provisions of this Section,
and Wis. Stats. Sec. 342.40 and Wis. Stats. Sec. 779.415, the provisions of
state law shall govern.
10.0404 DISPOSAL OF ABANDONED VEHICLES
Any abandoned vehicle impounded by the City of Marinette, which has not been
reclaimed, junked, or sold by direct sale to a licensed salvage dealer pursuant to
City of Marinette 41 Code of Ordinances
the provisions of this Chapter, may be sold by public auction sale, or public sale
calling for the receipt of sealed bids. Class 1 Notice, including the description of
the vehicle, the name(s) and address(s) of the Wisconsin titled owner and secured
party of record, if known, and the time of sale, shall be published before the sale.
10.0405 REPORT OF SALE OR DISPOSAL
Within five (5) days after the direct sale or disposal of a vehicle as provided for
herein, the Chief of Police or his designee shall advise the State of Wisconsin
Department of Transportation, Division of Motor Vehicles, of such sale or
disposal on a form supplied by said Division. A copy of the form shall be given to
the purchaser of the vehicle.
10.0406 OWNER RESPONSIBLE FOR IMPOUNDMENT AND DISPOSAL COSTS
The owner of any abandoned vehicle, except a stolen vehicle, is responsible for
the abandonment and all costs of impounding and disposing of the vehicle. Costs
not covered from the sale of the vehicle may be recovered in a civil action by the
City against the owner.
10.0407 CONFLICT WITH OTHER CODE PROVISIONS
In the event of any conflict between this section and any other provisions of this
Municipal Code, this Chapter shall control.
10.0408 JUNKED VEHICLES AND APPLIANCES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY
A. Storage of Automobiles Restricted
1. No disassembled, inoperable, unlicensed, junked, or wrecked motor
vehicles, truck bodies, tractors, trailers, or appliances shall be stored
or allowed to remain in the open upon private property within the City
for a period exceeding twenty (20) days unless it is in connection with
a properly licensed automotive or appliance sales, repair, or storage
business enterprise located in a properly zoned area.
2. Any business engaged in automotive sales or repair may retain such
vehicles in the open, on private property, for a period not to exceed
three (3) months, after which such vehicles must be enclosed by a
screening or live planting to be approved by the Plan Commission.
B. Definitions
1. The term "disassembled, inoperable, junked, or wrecked motor
vehicles, truck bodies, tractors, trailers" as used in this section is
defined as follows: motor vehicles, truck bodies, tractors, or trailers in
such state of physical or mechanical ruin as to be incapable of
propulsion or being operated upon the public streets or highways.
2. The term "unlicensed - motor vehicles, truck bodies, tractors or
trailers" as used in this Chapter is defined as follows: motor vehicles,
truck bodies, tractors or trailers which do not bear lawful current
City of Marinette 42 Code of Ordinances
license plates.
3. The term "motor vehicle" is defined in Section 340.01(35), Wis. Stats.
4. The term "inoperable appliance" is defined as any stove, washer, or
refrigerator, which is no longer operable in the sense for which it was
manufactured.
C. Exceptions
This Section shall not apply to any motor vehicle or motor vehicle
accessories stored within an enclosed building or on the premises of a
business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner when necessary
to the operation of such business enterprise, in a storage place or depository
maintained in a lawful place and manner, or seasonal use vehicles such as
snowmobiles, motorcycles, motor scooters and non-motorized campers,
provided such vehicles are stored in rear yard areas. Such business
enterprises shall include auto junkyards, auto repair and body shops but
shall not include automobile service stations or tire, battery, and accessory
sales stores, except those service stations, which operate a duly licensed
wrecker service. Also excepted are motor vehicles registered pursuant to
Sections 341.265 and 341.266, Wis. Stats. In other situations the Chief of
Police may issue permits permitting an extension of not to exceed an
additional thirty (30) days time to comply with this section where
exceptional facts and circumstances warrant such extension.
D. Enforcement
1. Whenever the Police Department shall find any vehicles or
appliances, as described herein, placed or stored in the open upon
private property within the City, they shall notify the owner of said
property on which said vehicle or appliance is stored of the violation
of this Section. If said vehicle or appliance is not removed within five
(5) days, the Police Department shall cause to be issued a citation to
the property owner or tenant of the property upon which said vehicle
or appliance is stored.
2. If such vehicle or appliance is not removed within twenty (20) days
after issuance of a citation, the Chief of Police shall cause the vehicle
or appliance to be removed and impounded and it shall thereafter be
disposed of as prescribed in Sections 10.0403 through 10.0406 by the
Chief of Police or his duly authorized representative. Any cost
incurred in the removal and sale of said vehicle or appliance shall be
recovered from the owner. However, if the owner of the vehicle or
appliance cannot readily be found, the cost of such removal shall be
charged to the property from which it is removed, which charges shall
be entered as a special charge on the tax roll.
City of Marinette 43 Code of Ordinances
E. Penalty
Any person who shall interfere with the enforcement of any of the
provisions of this Section and shall be found guilty thereof shall be subject
to the general penalty as provided in Section 1.0107 of this Code. Each
motor vehicle or appliance involved shall constitute a separate offense.
State Law Reference: Section 342.40, Wis. Stats.
10.0500 NEIGHBORHOOD ELECTRIC VEHICLES
10.0501 Neighborhood electric vehicles
A. Definitions
1. Neighborhood electric vehicle means a self-propelled motor vehicle,
excluding golf carts, that has successfully completed the
Neighborhood Electric Vehicle America Test Program by the Federal
Department of Energy and that conforms to the definition and
requirements for low-speed vehicle under 49 CFR 571.3(b) and
571.500 and which is authorized under Wis. Stat. §349.26 and
340.01(36r).
2. Neighborhood electric vehicles shall not be operated on any highway
within the city of Marinette where the maximum speed limit exceeds
thirty-five (35) miles per hour.
3. A neighborhood electric vehicle shall be 4-wheeled and have a speed
range of at least 20 miles per hour and not more than 25 miles per
hour on a paved surface and have a gross vehicle weight of less than
2,500 pounds. Neighborhood electric vehicles shall have all of the
following specifications:
(a) Headlamps;
(b) Front and rear turn signals;
(c) Stop lamps;
(d) Reflex reflectors; one red on each side as far to the rear as
practicable and one red on the rear;
(e) An exterior mirror mounted on the driver’s side and either an
exterior mirror on the passenger side or an interior rearview
mirror;
(f) Parking brake;
(g) A windshield that conforms to the requirements of the federal
motor vehicles safety standard on glazing materials (49 CFR
571.205);
(h) A vehicle identification number (VIN) that complies with
federal law as provided in 949 CFR 565;
City of Marinette 44 Code of Ordinances
(i) A type 1 or type 2 seatbelt assembly conforming to 49 CFR
571.209 and federal motor vehicle standard no. 209 for each
designated seating position; and
(j) Meets the general test conditions under 49 CFR 571.50056.
B. Uses Permitted on City Streets
A licensed individual may operate a neighborhood electric vehicle on those
city streets having a posted speed limit of 35 miles per hour or less, and
headlamps must be on during operation.
C. License
Neighborhood electric vehicles shall be registered, titled and licensed by the
State of Wisconsin.
D. Permitted Users
Any person who operates a neighborhood electric vehicle on any City street
must hold a valid State of Wisconsin operator’s license. The operation of a
neighborhood electric vehicle must in all respects comply with Chapter 10
Section 10.0500 of the Marinette Code of Ordinances.
E. Penalty
Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall
forfeit any amount as provided in Section 1.0107.
(Ordinance 2008-2140 adopted 11-5-08)

SCHEDULE D
PARKING PROHIBITED AT CERTAIN TIMES
(a part of Section 10.0112)
(a) No person shall park a vehicle on the following streets between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.
of any day:
(1) City Court, south side, from Wells Street easterly one hundred twenty (120) feet.
(2) Liberty Street, northwest side, from Stephenson Street to a point four hundred
(400) feet southwest of the intersection with Stephenson Street.
(b) No person shall park a vehicle on the following streets between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m.,
Sundays excepted:
(1) In the space appurtenant to parking meter No. 265 on the north side of Stephenson
Street between Hall Avenue and Dunlap Avenue from 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 noon.
(2) In the space now appurtenant to parking meter No. 276 on the south side of
Stephenson Street in front of Ray Schultz Service Station.
(c) No person shall park a vehicle on the following streets between 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m.,
except on Sundays and holidays:
(1) North side of Grant Street, except on 1400 & 1500 blocks. (Ordinance 2013-2253
adopted 6-4-13).
(d) No person shall park a vehicle on the north side of Wisconsin Street between Stephenson
Street and Madison Avenue for more than two (2) hours between the hours of 8:00 a.m.
and 5:00 p.m.

standing on a temporary basis, between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 4:30 p.m., Monday
through Friday, on Hockridge Street, the west side, between a point five hundred (500)
feet south of Minnesota Street and a point eighty-three (83) feet south thereof; provided,
however, this provision shall not apply to school buses or other buses, and said area shall
be designated as "school bus parking only" during the designated hours.

following locations while school is in session:
a. West side of Hockridge Street beginning ½ block southwest from the
intersection of Hockridge and Minnesota Streets and continuing southwest
until the sidewalk that runs to the back entrance of Park School

(2) The south side of Cleveland Avenue from Pierce Avenue westerly to the east

City of Marinette 11-1 Code of Ordinances
CHAPTER 11: OFFENSES AND NUISANCES
11.0100 OFFENSES AGAINST STATE LAWS SUBJECT TO
FORFEITURE
The statutory provisions describing and defining regulations with respect to crimes against public
health and safety, property, sexual morality, government and administration, and peace and order
in all sections of the Wisconsin Statutes, as revised, are hereby adopted and by reference made a
part of this Chapter as if fully set forth herein. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by
any statute incorporated herein by reference is required to be performed or prohibited by this
Chapter. Therefore, if a Marinette City Police Officer has probable cause to believe that an
individual has committed a non-felony violation of the above-stated Wisconsin Statutes, in the
City of Marinette, Wisconsin, he or she has the discretion to issue a civil citation to said
individual such that said individual would be prosecuted for the alleged violation in the
Marinette Municipal Court as a civil ordinance violation, rather than refer the matter for criminal
prosecution to the Marinette County District Attorney. The penalties prescribed for violation of
any of its provisions shall be limited to a forfeiture; said forfeiture shall be levied upon anyone
violating any of the provisions of Section 11.0101 of the Municipal Code of the City of
Marinette in an amount as found in Section 1.0107 of this Code of Ordinances, together with the
costs of prosecution, and in default of the payment of said forfeiture and costs of prosecution
shall be imprisoned in the County Jail of the County of Marinette until such forfeiture and costs
are paid, but not exceeding ninety (90) days. Any future amendments, revisions, or modifications
of the Statutes incorporated herein by reference are intended to be made part of this Code.
(Ord. 2014-2283 adopted 5-6-14)
